Refer to this link for build results: https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/16432/

I ran a few perf tests on 5 r3.8xlarge nodes, caching with both `MEMORY_ONLY` and `MEMORY_AND_DISK`, and observed no significant performance regression that cannot be attributed to EC2 noise.

In terms of correctness, you can run the following in spark-shell as a sanity check

```
sc.parallelize(1 to 20 * 1000 * 1000, 1).persist().count()
```

With the default configuration (512MB executor memory), this job OOMs before the changes in this patch, but no longer does after the changes (because it doesn't attempt to cache the block in memory).

I will add the relevant tests in `BlockManagerSuite` shortly.
Refer to this link for build results: https://amplab.cs.berkeley.edu/jenkins/job/SparkPullRequestBuilder/16429/

Hi guys,

I have made a new commit which includes java examples in files "docs/mllib-clustering.md" and "docs/mllib-collaborative-filtering.md". These examples are equivalent to the scala examples provided in the documentation, with the only difference being that should be run by users as standalone applications.

Thanks,
Michael

Holding out on updating the docs until the python version is supported.
For the python version, any objections to using _jrdd to invoke the java version of sampleByKey? There's a rddsampler class that uses numpy when available for native random support. Do we need to follow suit? @mengxr

Thanks @sryza for the idea. I think it's OK to piggy back the communication in a heartbeat, but we should also allow the worker to explicitly ask the master for map statuses when a task demands more outputs. I'll look into it once you have that feature merged.

@miccagiann In Spark, we follow https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/SPARK/Spark+Code+Style+Guide
for Scala code style, while Java code should be similar. I'm going to mark some style issues inline. Please update the code. Thanks!
